article.title: Finite searches, Chowla's cosine problem, and large Newman polynomials

response:
## Quiz Questions based on Scientific Article Figures and Formulas

This scientific article does not contain any figures. However, we can create multiple choice quiz questions based on formulas and definitions within the text.

**Question 1:** 

**Which formula defines the minimum value of a length *n* cosine sum f(θ) on the interval [0, π]?**

a)  M(a₁, ..., aₙ) = min<sub>|z|=1</sub> |z<sup>a₁</sup> + ... + z<sup>aₙ</sup>| 
b)  L(a₁, ..., aₙ) = min<sub>θ</sub> f(θ) = min<sub>0≤θ≤π</sub> f(θ)
c)  −λ(n) = sup L(a₁, ..., aₙ)
d)  µ(n) = sup M(a₁, ..., aₙ)

**Correct Answer:** b) L(a₁, ..., aₙ) = min<sub>θ</sub> f(θ) = min<sub>0≤θ≤π</sub> f(θ)

**Question 2:**

**What does the symbol µ(n) represent in the context of this article?**

a) The minimum value of a length *n* cosine sum.
b) The largest minimum modulus on the unit circle of a length *n* Newman polynomial. 
c)  The average value of a length *n* cosine sum on the interval [0, π].
d) The order of an equispaced subset of T. 

**Correct Answer:** b) The largest minimum modulus on the unit circle of a length *n* Newman polynomial. 

**Question 3:** 

**The article defines an equispaced subset of T of order m. Which of the following represents this definition?**

a)  {θ ∈ T | mθ = ξ}
b)  {θ₀ + 2kπ/m | k ∈ Z} 
c)  N′<sub>n</sub> = {(a₁, ..., a<sub>n</sub>) | 0 < a₁ < ... < a<sub>n</sub>, gcd(a₁, ..., a<sub>n</sub>) = 1}
d)  N″<sub>n</sub> = {(0, a₂, ..., a<sub>n</sub>) | 0 < a₂ < ... < a<sub>n</sub>, gcd(a₂, ..., a<sub>n</sub>) = 1, a<sub>n-1</sub> ≥ a<sub>n</sub> - a₂}

**Correct Answer:** b) {θ₀ + 2kπ/m | k ∈ Z}

**Question 4:** 

**The article utilizes a "dot product" for real-valued functions on T over an equispaced set S. What is the formula for this dot product?**

a)  <f(θ), g(θ)><sub>S</sub> = (1/m) Σ<sub>θ∈S</sub> f(θ)g(θ) 
b)  <f(θ), g(θ)><sub>S</sub> =  Σ<sub>θ∈S</sub> f(θ) + g(θ)
c)  <f(θ), g(θ)><sub>S</sub> =  f(θ)g(θ)
d)  <f(θ), g(θ)><sub>S</sub> =  m/ Σ<sub>θ∈S</sub> f(θ)g(θ)

**Correct Answer:** a) <f(θ), g(θ)><sub>S</sub> = (1/m) Σ<sub>θ∈S</sub> f(θ)g(θ)
